instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.BLK_EN: What is BLK_EN? This is a typo of BKL_EN When you see BLK_EN, assume they meant to type BKL_EN.
definitions.BLK_PWM: What is BLK_PWM? BLK_PWM is a typo of BKL_PWM. When you see BLK_PWM assume the poster meant to type BKL_PWM. BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message:
working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook air with no backlight(why does it seem i suck at this.) so what I've found is that i have no backlight enable coming from <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>.

pin 1 has 0.0v
pin 2 has 3.33v
pin 4 has 0.0v
pin 5 has 3.33v
pin 6 has 0.0v

i chased the backlight reset to <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> coming from the pch. kinda lost on possibilities.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message: Pin 2 and 5 are both high, what is the issue? What is the backlight output on <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>? Is there an image on the LCD for sure?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message: The issue is no backlight on screen. there is video on the lcd, i put a light on the back of the screen and ran ASD on it. the voltage on <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> pin 1 is 8.06v and 8.04 v on pin2.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message:
So the enable is not missing or you would have no voltage on <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>. Also 8.06V would be on battery, on AC it should be 8.4V.
Was this liquid damaged?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message: yes i did test on battery. i have no idea if it had water damage before i got to it. i did take it out of the case didn't see water damage and water indicators are still white. i am missing the voltage to pin 3 which is <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> still. but no backlight to screen i did test with a known working screen also.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message: What is the voltage on pin 3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message: Diode mode on both pins of <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> with red to GND?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message: pretty sure u meant <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>. pin 1 is .970 pin 2 is 1.37

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message:
something makes no sense here.

What voltage is on <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> pin 2?
What do you get on <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> pin 2 for <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>?
d <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, do you have continuity between ball A5(<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT_FB</SIGNAL>) and pin 2 of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message:
yes this is a strange one.

pin 2 on <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> is 0.13v <SIGNAL>BLK_PWM</SIGNAL>
pin 2 on <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> is 2.84v <SIGNAL>BLK_EN</SIGNAL>
yes continuity between ball 5 to pin 2 of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message: Check resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>, if not low do a PRAM reset.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message: 172kh resistance to ground at <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR>. it seems like the <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> is getting what it needs to send the <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> signal but just isn't sending it out. gonna try to change it and see what happens.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message:
You really do not understand how this works. <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> is fine, there is 8.4V on <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>. Are you measuring without an LCD again?
<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> is missing, this is due to backlight being set all the way down in OS or a bad PCH or a bad <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message:
Let's go back.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> allows <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to pass through to the system. <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> is a P channel so it will open when voltage on the gate is lower than the source.

There is a voltage divider in place that allows the voltage on the gate of <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> to be lower than the source. It only works when <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> is allowing that voltage divider a path to ground.

If you have voltage passing through <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>, stop looking at <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>. That part works fine.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message:
sorry guys some times i get a little ahead of myself. All measurements have been with lcd connected. i have done a PRAM reset. I've even booted it into ASD os and EFI with no failures. Don't know the exact history of this machine didn't see water damage or any signs of an issue. 

I'm hoping its not a bad PCH, when i search on open board viewer for <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> nothing come back. Im guessing this one is gonna go to the " look at this another time" stack.

thanks for all the help.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message: <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> is the chip model identifier. On boardview and schematic, it's <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>. If you replace <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and still have no backlight, you're either missing something obvious (i.e. bad fuse) or it's the PCH. Be done with this one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight enable missing.
threads.message:
After replacing the <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> backlight has been restored and everything is working correctly. 

Thank you again.
